headline.main: F.D.A. MAY WARN ON DRUGS IN PREGNANCY

byline.original: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is considering a requirement that all over-the-counter drugs include a warning against their discretionary use by pregnant women, according to Dr. James M. Bilstad, acting director of the agency's Office of New Drug Evaluation. ''No drug has been proven 100 percent safe for the unborn and we can't say there is no risk,'' he said. ''Some risks are so small we can't detect them in laboratory or clinical trials.'' The agency has not determined the wording for the warning or set a date when it might appear on labels, he added.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S the eighth inning and, with the Kansas City Royals threatening to wipe out the New York Yankees' slim lead, Rich Gossage comes to the mound for the save. As the camera zooms in on the windup for his 100-mile-an-hour fast ball, a chipmunklike bulge appears in his cheek. It is a wad of tobacco, which baseball players and other athletes have long favored and have lately been promoting nationwide in commercials and, intentionally or otherwise, on televised games. The macho image they bring to this smokeless form of tobacco has begun to rub off. Sales are climbing fast, especially among the young. One California high school had to set aside spitting areas to keep the dark brown blotches from littering the entire campus. The spittoon, it would seem, is about to make a comeback.
